docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am disappointed to hear prominent Democrats distancing themselves from abortion rights.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I am disappointed to hear prominent Democrats distancing themselves from abortion rights.

docs.lead_paragraph: The holidays have a way of turning simple sadness into tragedy, chance encounters into magic, and mere good luck into a miracle. That was the case on Christmas Eve in Elmhurst, Queens, when a cab driver called 911 to report that his passenger was giving birth and he did not know the way to the nearest hospital. One of the first people to reach the scene was Police Officer Ivy Dror, a certified emergency medical technician. Not only did Officer Dror, 23, help deliver a healthy baby girl, she handed a Polaroid camera to the cab driver and asked him to document the baby's first minutes.

headline.main: Baby's First Stop? A Taxi in Queens

docs.abstract: Police officer Ivy Dror delivers baby in taxicab in Queens on Christmas Day; uses shoelace to tie umbilical cord that had become entangled around mothers leg; photo (M)
docs.snippet: On Christmas Eve in Elmhurst, Queens, a police officer helped a woman give birth to her daughter in a cab.

docs.lead_paragraph: There had been signs it might come to this, this secret stashing away of a life. A manager at the Folies-Bergère asked Margaret Kelly to put together a new troupe of her famous British dancing girls, the Bluebells. As for Kelly herself -- Miss Bluebell, she was called -- the manager suggested she refrain from appearing at the theater. Kelly's husband was Jewish, and with the invasion of the Germans looking imminent, the theater wasn't willing to risk its reputation, Kelly was told. Within six months, the Germans had overrun Paris and Kelly's husband had fled, eventually returning to a hidden life in an apartment on the Left Bank. Although many of the nightclubs went dark, for most of her husband's two-and-a-half-year seclusion, Kelly kept directing a small line of dancers at a modest dance hall. Kelly made the most of the sequins and feathered caps and food-rationed girls she could get her hands on, creating a show for an audience seeking denial or defiance, conjuring the vestiges of glamour from a city that reeked, at the time, of defeat and deprivation, of humiliation, even of hunger. Every week, Kelly got on her bicycle, pedaled west, up the inclined slope of the city, to reach a man who could sell her vegetables. The basket on her bike full, she headed back toward her husband's secret home across the Seine. She brought him magazines, stationery, his mended clothing. She brought him herself, her devotion, unperturbed by the risks she was taking, all of them punishable by death. She was six months pregnant when the Gestapo called her in the first time to interrogate her about her husband, whom they knew had been missing for considerably longer than her condition would suggest -- a high-risk pregnancy, indeed. After each interrogation, she'd bike home and expunge the house, in a panic, of any hint of her husband, the men's briefs fresh from the wash, the clean undershirts. He was never discovered.

headline.main: Margaret Kelly [ b. 1910 ]; The Hidden Life of Miss Bluebell

docs.snippet: She used glamour to ward off tragedy.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Katharina Dalton knew about PMS: the bloating, the misery, the crankiness, the cramps. Premenstrual migraines thrummed in her skull. In her mid-20's, she was a chiropodist in London. In 1942, she became pregnant with her first son. Some of us muddle our way through those nine months. Dalton felt fine. Now that she was high on hormones and packed with progesterone, the migraines that had plagued her since she was an adolescent went away. Pregnancy shapes the social and emotional lives of many women, though rarely does it help define a career. But it prompted Dalton to wonder what exactly was the connection between those sex steroids we call hormones and that omnipotent invisibility we call mood. She came to believe that pregnancy -- during which progesterone levels are sky high -- was a time of serenity. It made sense, then, that the misery preceding some women's periods might be the result of inadequate progesterone production. She went back to school for medicine, a lifelong dream. In her first months as a general practitioner, she identified and treated patients with premenstrually related asthma, epilepsy and migraines by dosing them with progesterone. She had taken it herself, too, after Dr. Raymond Greene, a colleague, recommended the treatment.

headline.main: Katharina Dalton [ b. 1916 ]; The Prophet of PMS

docs.snippet: By naming an affliction, she helped liberate women from its pain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Diabetes killed an increasing number of New York City residents last year, ranking for the first time among the five leading causes of death in an annual summary of vital statistics released yesterday by the health department. Diabetes was identified as the fourth-leading cause with 1,891 deaths in 2003, an 11 percent increase from the previous year, when the disease was ranked sixth, according to the summary. Of those deaths, 1,024 were women and 867 were men.

headline.main: Diabetes Is Gaining As a Cause of Death, City Health Data Say

docs.abstract: Diabetes killed 1,891 New York City residents in 2003, fourth leading cause of death, and for first time is one of city's five leading causes of death, says Health Dept; is 11 percent increase over 2002, when it ranked sixth; 2003 deaths break down to 1,024 women and 867 men; officials attributed increase to rising levels of obesity and higher risk in population that is living longer; other health statistics reported (M)
